factoid: Kutúzov reached the village and sat in the shade of the nearest house on a bench.

Pierre stopped some thirty paces from Kutúzov and spoke to Borís.
Pierre explained his wish to be present at the battle and to see the position.
Borís told Pierre that he would do the honors of the camp for Pierre.
Borís told Pierre that Pierre would see everything best from where Count Bennigsen will be.

Borís told Pierre that he would mention Pierre to Count Bennigsen.

Pierre said that he could do that later, but the chief thing is the left flank.

Borís told Pierre that he was just trying to explain their position to Count Bennigsen.
Kaysárov asked if the left flank was the subject.
Borís said that the left flank is now extremely strong.
Kutúzov had dismissed unnecessary men from the staff.
Borís remained at headquarters after the changes.
Borís established himself with Count Bennigsen.
Count Bennigsen considered young Prince Drubetskóy an invaluable man.
In higher command there were two parties: Kutúzov’s party and Bennigsen’s party, the chief of staff.
Borís belonged to Bennigsen’s party.
Borís showed servile respect to Kutúzov.
Borís could create an impression that Kutúzov was not much good and that Bennigsen managed everything.

Borís was full of nervous vivacity all day.
After Kaysárov, others whom Pierre knew approached him.
Pierre had no time to reply to all questions about Moscow that were showered upon him.
Pierre could not listen to all that was told him.
The faces all expressed animation and apprehension.
The cause of excitement seemed to be questions of personal success.
Pierre’s mind was occupied by the expression he saw on other faces, which spoke of universal questions of life and death.
Kutúzov noticed Pierre’s figure and the group gathered around him.
Kutúzov said to call him to him.

Pierre went toward Kutúzov’s bench.
